data.title: Press any key to close message gets written before process output is finished for background terminals
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: master

I can a task and request the terminal to print the 'Press any key to close the terminal' message. However the message is printed to the terminal before the actual output of the task.

```
Press any key to close the terminal
 Volume in drive C is OSDisk
 Volume Serial Number is A63A-8EB4

 Directory of c:\Users\dirkb\Projects\mseng\VSCode\Playgrounds\tasks\client

22-Mar-17  21:34    <DIR>          .
22-Mar-17  21:34    <DIR>          ..
22-Mar-17  22:17                34 client.js
22-Mar-17  22:17                97 client.js.map
17-Feb-17  18:29                 0 client.ts
               3 File(s)            131 bytes
               2 Dir(s)  354,157,559,808 bytes free
```

I actually run two tasks in two terminal in parallel. The task in the terminal that is in front prints correctly to the terminal. The other not. In addition to the wrong placement of the message the terminal doesn't have a scroll bar either.

data.title: Debugging Node.js application
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04
- Node.js: 7.7.3

If you're using latest Node.js version there's no `legacy` protocol, you need to use `inspector`. I suggest to auto include `"protocol": "auto"` to `launch.json` config. Because right now to debug Node.js app, I need to create `launch.json` just to include `"protocol": "auto"`.

data.title: Feature #22768
data.body: Fixes #22768

data.title: Key bindings for command+# to select the nth tab
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6 (El Capitan)

In a number of other Mac programs (Firefox, Chrome, Atom, etc.) you can hit Command (Apple) + a number key to switch to the nth tab. So if I have 3 tabs open and I hit command+2, it'll switch over to the 2nd tab. In VSCode there are keybinding commands to do `workbench.action.focusSecondEditorGroup`, but it would be nice to have `workbench.action.focusSecondEditor` or `workbench.action.focusSecondTab` or something like that.

Any ideas?

data.title: Configuration service doesn't report parseErrors anymore

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: master

Following tasks.json. It clearly has a parse error since the array for the first args is not closed.
```json
{
    "version": "2.0.0",  
    "echoCommand": true,
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "tsc",
            "command": ".\\node_modules\\.bin\\tsc.cmd",
            "args": [
                "-w"
            ,
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "isBackground": true,
            "problemMatcher": "$tsc-watch",
            "isBuildCommand": true
        },
        {
            "taskName": "dir",
            "command": "dir",  
            "options": {
                "cwd": "p:\\tmp"
            },
            "isShellCommand": true,  
            "showOutput": "always",
            "dependsOn": ["dir2"]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "dir2",
            "command": "dir",
            "options": {
                "cwd": "C:\\Users\\dirkb"
            },
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "showOutput": "always"
        },
        {
            "taskName": "super",
            "dependsOn": ["dir"]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "Expand Issue",
            "command": "echo %HOMEDRIVE%%HOMEPATH%",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "isBackground": false
        },
        {
            "taskName": "Path",
            "command": "echo",
            "args": [
                "%PATH%"
            ],
            "isShellCommand": true
        },
        {
            "taskName": "Client Build",
            "command": "dir",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "options": {
                "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/client"
            }

        },
        {
            "taskName": "Server Build",
            "command": "dir",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "options": {
                "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/server"
            }
        },
        {
            "taskName": "Build",
            "dependsOn": ["Client Build", "Server Build"]
        }
    ]
}
```
```ts
this.configurationService.getConfiguration<TaskConfig.ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration>('tasks');
```

doesn't report any parse errors (e.g $parseErrors not set on the returned object)

data.title: [scss] parse problem with parent selector
Treat file-reload as an undoable "edit".
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331
- OS Version: N/A

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have a file open in VSCode.
2. Change the file outside VSCode.
3. In VSCode, the file reloads automatically.
4. Realise that you didn't mean to make that change.
5. Apply palm to face.

Some other editors treat the reloading of the file as an edit. This gives the careless user a reprieve if they accidentally blow away work on the command line (`git checkout .`, anyone?). They can simply invoke undo to get back to the state the file was in before the mishap.

This would also preserve undo history in the event of a reload.

data.title: Double-click on list items should provide consistent editor pinning

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (32942fd950cf2ffe19c44f944170014704b4fd2c, 2017-03-22T07:05:02.334Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0

---

Double-clicking on a file in the explorer will open an editor for that file "pinned", but double-clicking on a file in the SCM viewlet doesn't do anything different than a single click. Same with the peek ui (find reference for example). I think it would be great if the double-click behavior was consistent across these (basically anything that could open an editor and double-click shouldn't mean something else).

data.title: Debugging a language service when
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 . also does the same thing with today's insider.
- OS Version: Win10 15061.

I’m building/launching/debugging the Extension Development Host (and the oop server process) fine from vscode, but if I ‘open a folder’, it restarts the Extension Development Host vscode process, and apparently doesn’t load the extension at that point.  (and the debuggers have stopped, since the original processes went away). The status bar also turns from purple to blue.

If I exit that process and restart from my main vscode again, it starts up the new EHD process in the folder that I previously opened (and the status bar is blue), but doesn’t break on any breakpoints in the client and fails to attach to the server. I’m pretty sure that my extension isn’t actually loading in that process (as the stuff I write to the console and/or status bar don’t  show up).

*Is* there a means to debug when vscode is in ‘open a folder’ mode?

data.title: freeze after opening large js file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. download pixi.js file here: https://pixijs.download/v4.4.1/pixi.js
2. open it in vscode.

The file has 32000 lines. Syntax coloring is performed, but not in all the file, in minimap I can see that the rest of the file is colored some seconds later. Then some seconds later vscode becomes unresponsive and the "reopen/KeepWaiting/Close" window appears.
vscode doesn't respond anymore.

Notes:
- I disabled all installed extensions.
- removed all user settings
- using process explorer, code.exe processes have very small CPU usage (<0.01), but when I open the file, one process jumps to 24. This process has the following command line: 
`"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\Code.exe" --type=renderer --no-sandbox --primordial-pipe-token=D0E6B099F12CB44DAE1CB652861134C3 --lang=fr --app-user-model-id=Microsoft.VisualStudioCode --node-integration=true --background-color=#1E1E1E --enable-pinch --device-scale-factor=1 --num-raster-threads=2 --content-image-texture-target=3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553 --video-image-texture-target=3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553,3553 --mojo-channel-token=8E822E8C334181933F23B0D47B4CCF45 --mojo-application-channel-token=D0E6B099F12CB44DAE1CB652861134C3 --channel="4072.2.1646610899\347217882" --mojo-platform-channel-handle=2508 /prefetch:1`

data.title: Enable contributable Application menu

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Having a contributable application menu seems like a inevitable feature coming since the `menus.ts` is growing more and more and every feature has its part in there. We'd like to disconnect all of that and have contributions come in with menu items. For example, the whole Debug menu should come in via the debug part.

For this to happen, we've come up with the following plan:

1. Create a `CommandService` in the Main process, which simply forwards command calls to the active window.
2. Create a `MenuRegistry` and `MenuService` in the main process. Figure out how to work around the fact that it requires a `ContextKeyService` (make it optional?) and how to get sub-menus in there.
3. Adopt the whole application menu from `menus.ts` into MenuItems. Create a new menu id for the Application menu. Should it be only 1? Should the `File` be one, the `Edit` be another, etc?
4. Whenever each renderer contributes menuitems to a menu that _lives_ in the main process, we need to serialize those calls to the `MenuRegistry` over to the main process.

@bpasero @jrieken Thoughts?

data.title: [Feature Request] Allow to open a new Editor for a file in the Search Side Bar
data.body: Implement a capability to open a new editor for a file in the Search Side Bar. As of now the only option is to replace the currently opened editor (by selecting a file in the Search Side Bar), which often is not very convenient. I would even say the current behavior is buggy. :)

data.title: [Feature Request] Allow drag-and-drop files from search side bar to Editor/Open Editors
data.body: Implement a capability to drag files from the Search Side Bar and drop them into Editor or Open Editors for subsequent editing.
